summary.p: The Attuvaitāṉupavam, “Experience of Non-Duality” (Sanskrit advaita + anubhava), is a philosophical text, of which there seems to exist no printed edition yet. According to the preface (f76) and the final colophon (f95), the author is Rāmakavi, disciple of Civarāmakavi (Sanskrit Śivarāmakavi), himself disciple of Navamakāleṭcumi Nāraciṅkatēcikar (Sanskrit Navamahālakṣmī Nārasiṃhadeśika). In the present manuscript the work consists of 128 stanzas.
The titles of the 12 chapters, as given in the manuscript, are:

filiation.p: Other manuscript testimonies of this text are kept in the GOML: D. 1428–1430 (Kuppuswami Sastri 1927, pp. 1240–2), R. 1342 (Fazlullah and Chandrasekharan 1949, p. 2228). See also Chandrasekharan (1951: n° 106).

collation.desc: 1 folio, unfoliated = title-page, by hand n° 1.

21 folios, parallel Tamil foliation 2‒20 (f1 not explicitly foliated) and Tamil foliation 76‒95 = text (mūlam). We find successively: invocatory stanza (f75r); 3 stanzas of pāyiram, “preface” (f76r‒f76v), also titled kuruvaṇakkam (f76r, lm and f76v1), “hommage to preceptor”; main text (mūlam) (f77r‒f94v), divided in 12 chapters, each of 10 stanzas; a kind of postface in 4 stanzas (f95r‒f95v), explaining the origin of the work.

supportDesc.condition: Very good state of preservation, in spite of bore holes caused by insects.

handNote.desc: 8 to 10 lines per page (most often 9), by hand n° 2.

binding.p: Mahogany woodcovers apparently fabricated in the BnF.

origin.origDate: No internal date. Before 1855, as it is part of Ariel’s bequest made in that year to the Société Asiatique, Paris (Rosny 1869). Ca. 1835 according to Vinson (1867-1868, p. 1) and Cabaton (1912, p. 54). The reason for this date is unknown.

acquisition.p: Bequest of Edouard Ariel. Made first to Société Asiatique de Paris in 1855, later transfered to Bibliothèque Nationale (see Rosny 1869).

encodingDesc.p: Transliteration conventions. Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Conjectural (whether the text is not clearly legible or the character is ambigous, e.g. kāl or length of o and e) readings between parentheses. Alternative readings between parentheses separated by slash. Lost or entirely illegible character: "?". Crossed-out character: "X". Conjectural restoration of lost or entirely illegible between square brackets. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). Unquoted text represented by (...). Conjunct letter: e.g. t°, to be read tum or tam. Grantha letters in bold. Symbols/Abbreviations made explicit, between curly brackets: {pcs} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, short form; {pcl} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, long form, that is, with long horizontal stroke towards right; {varuṣam}, {mācam}, {tēti}; {line-filler}. Unfoliated folio number between square brackets, e.g. "f[1]r". Numerals normalised to decimal notation, e.g. "1121" not "1000 1 100 2 10 1". Hyphen occasionaly used to mark in-word components. Hyphen systematically used at the end of a line when the line-beginning is within a word or within a cīr. Sandhi split to the minimum: overshort u occasionally restored as an apostrophe. Stanzas split by cīr, as far as possible. aṭi boundary marked by "‡".

Abbreviations. c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso. GOML = Government Oriental Manuscripts Library, Madras/Chennai. MTL = Madras Tamil Lexicon. TMSSML = Tanjore Maharaja Serfoji Sarasvati Mahal Library.
